Integral representations of hermitian forms over local fields
By Arnold A.  Johnson at Madison ( Wisconsin ) ^ )
A reflexive form q^ which is obtained from a given form Ç by a linear substitution of any number of new variables,  is said to be represented by Q.  As a special case,  we have the notion of equivalence of forms,  the linear substitution then being a change of variables that can be inverted over the basic coefficient ring.  Hermitian and quadratic forms are two of the three main types of reflexive forms ( cf.  [ 4 ] ).  Several results concerning valence and representation of these forms have been obtained over rings and fields of arithmetic type.  The questions of fractional equivalence and representation as well as local integral equivalence have been solved for both quadratic and hermitian forms ( cf.  [ 5 ],  [ 6 ],  [ 7 ],  [ 11 ] ).  Partial solutions to the problem of local integral representation of quadratic forms have been obtained by O'Meara [ 10 ] and Riehm [ 12 ].  Global results on the equivalence of hermitian forms have been obtained by Shimura [ 13 ].  Böge [ 2 ] has obtained similar global results for anti - hermitian forms. 
The purpose of this paper is to present necessary and sufficient conditions for gral representation of hermitian forms over local fields of characteristic 4=2.  Although the hermitian theory of forms often follows quickly once the corresponding quadratic theory is known,  the local integral representation theory for quadratic forms is still incomplete and finding a general solution there appears to be very difficult.  The solution to the question of local integral representation of hermitian forms is obtained through three cases.  We are given a local field E ( of characteristic Ф 2 ) with a non - trivial tion,  *.  Let F be the fixed field of *.  Then the three cases considered are those where the field extension EjF is ( 1 ) unramified,  ( 2 ) ramified with E non - dyadic and ( 3 ) ramified with E dyadic.  The question of integral representation in the first two cases is reduced to that of fractional representation ; the solution to the latter is already known.
